moves.6. e4 Nxc3 7. bxc3 c5 8. Bc4 O-O 9. O-O: More promising is 10... PxP 11 PxP N-B3, to be followed with ...P-QN3 and ...B-N2.
moves.14. Ne1: A very important move, which prevents the Black Knight from blockading the passed pawn.
moves.14... Bd6 15. Nc2 Re8 16. Bd3 Nf8 17. Ne: This move not only keeps Black's Knight from KB5, it also prepares the strategically important move P-KB4.
moves.18... Bb7 19. Nc4: A strategical maneuver where White prepares to exchange the blockading piece.
moves.19... Reb8 20. Be3: An inaccuracy. Correct was the immediate exchange of the blockading Bishop.
moves.20... Bc8 21. Nxd6: White doesn't miss his chance this time.
moves.21... Qxd6 22. f3 h5 23. Qf2: This move prepares P-KB4 and forces the blocking of the Q side.
moves.23... a5 24. f4: The threat is 25 P-B5 N-B1 26 B-K2 P-N3 27 PxP PxP 28 R-KB1 R-R2 29 Q-B6.
27 P-K5 is also strong, but White is unwilling to allow Black any counterplay.
moves.27... Bh3 28. Bxh3 Qxh3 29. Qg3 Qh4: 30 QxQ NxQ 31 K-B2 R-K1 32 P-K5 would now give White the superior endgame.
moves.30. Bf2 Qf6: 30... QxBP? 31 QxQ NxQ 32 B-N3 P-Kn4 33 BxN PxB 34 P-B4 is a won game for White.
moves.31. f5: White intends to exchange Black's Knight and make use of his protected passed pawn in the ensuing end game.
moves.31... Ne5 32. Kh1 Rbe8 33. Re2 Ng4 34. B: If 38... N-B3, 39 R/1-K1 threatens B-B7 and Q-N3.
moves.39. Kxh2 Re5 40. Rg1 Rd7: Better is 40... K-B1 41 P-B4, where the win is more difficult for White.
moves.41. Reg2 f6 42. Re2: By this Rook maneuver, White has shut off the Black Q, which can now be exchanged.
moves.42... Kh8 43. c4 Kg8 44. Rge1 Kf8 45. Qg: White now sacrifices the protected passed pawn in return for winning the pawn on QN6, enabling his Rooks to invade Black's position.
Black resigns, as after 54... R/4-K2 55 R-N8 ch K-B2 56 R/5-Q8, Black cannot avoid decisive material loss.

players: Svetozar Gligorich  vs. Luis Augusto Sanchez
